reg:regulation.reg:title: Provincial Sales Tax Exemption and Refund Regulation
reg:regulation.reg:amsincluded: [Last amended July 1, 2023 by B.C. Reg. 128/2023 and includes amendments by B.C. Reg. 165/2023]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this regulation:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Act means the Provincial Sales Tax Act;
alcohol-containing food product means a food product that contains alcohol and also contains ingredients that make the food product unsuitable for use as an intoxicant;
First Nation land means land that is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a reserve, or
treaty lands of a treaty first nation

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: that were, immediately before the effective date of the treaty first nation's final agreement, a reserve or surrendered lands, and
in respect of which a First Nation individual's property is exempt from taxation under section 87 of the Indian Act (Canada) or under a provision of a final agreement equivalent to that section;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: fishing equipment includes the tangible personal property described in Schedule 3 [Fishing Equipment for Commercial Fishing Purpose];
francophone school has the same meaning as in the School Act;
heating oil has the same meaning as in the Motor Fuel Tax Act;
mineral means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: metal ore or a natural substance that can be mined and that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: occurs in fragments or particles lying on, above or adjacent to the bedrock source from which it is derived, and is commonly described as talus,
is in the place or position in which it was originally formed or deposited, or
is loose, fragmentary or broken rock or float that, by decomposition or erosion of rock, is found in wash, loose earth, gravel or sand, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: tailings, building and construction stone, marble, shale, clay, sand and gravel,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include petroleum, natural gas, volcanic ash, earth, soil, marl or peat;
Nisg̱a'a Nation has the same meaning as in the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement, as defined in the Nisg̱a'a Final Agreement Act;
obtain means,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of tangible personal property,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to purchase the tangible personal property,
to lease the tangible personal property as a lessee,
to bring or send into British Columbia, or receive delivery of in British Columbia, the tangible personal property, or
to receive the tangible personal property as a gift, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of Part 4 software, to purchase or use the Part 4 software;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: Part 3 software means software that is subject to tax or exempt from tax under Part 3 of the Act;
Part 4 software means software other than Part 3 software;
practitioner has the same meaning as in the Pharmacy Operations and Drug Scheduling Act;
prescription means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a formula or direction, given by a practitioner, for a remedy or treatment for a disease or disorder;
an assessment record or a contact lens record, as those terms are defined in the Opticians Regulation, B.C. Reg. 118/2010;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: primary aquaculture product means an aquatic animal or aquatic plant grown or raised for sale, but does not include a processed or manufactured product or an aquarium specimen;
Provincial school has the same meaning as in the School Act;
qualifying agricultural use has the same meaning as in the Classification of Land as a Farm Regulation, B.C. Reg. 411/95;
qualifying aquaculturist means a person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: who carries on an aquaculture business,
who holds a licence issued under

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: section 24 (1) of the Fisheries Act (British Columbia), or
the Pacific Aquaculture Regulations made under the Fisheries Act (Canada), and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in respect of whom either of the following applies:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the person produced

bcl:clause.bcl:text: under any licence referred to in paragraph (b) that is held by that person,
during the immediately preceding calendar year, and
at that person's place of production,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: primary aquaculture products with a gross market value of not less than $7 500;
the person reasonably expects to produce

bcl:clause.bcl:text: under any licence referred to in paragraph (b) that is held by that person,
in the calendar year in which the last licence referred to in paragraph (b) was issued to that person or in one of the 4 calendar years following that calendar year, and
at that person's place of production,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: primary aquaculture products with a gross market value of not less than $7 500;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: qualifying commercial fisher means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fishes for commercial purposes under the authority of the Fisheries Act (Canada), and
received, in the immediately preceding calendar year, from commercial fishing in waters in or adjacent to British Columbia,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: not less than $10 000 in gross income, or
at least 51% of the person's total gross income;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: qualifying farmer means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: an owner, as defined in section 1 (1) of the Assessment Act, of land classified as a farm under that Act, or
a lessee of land classified as a farm under that Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: who is

bcl:clause.bcl:text: an owner, as defined in section 1 (1) of the Assessment Act, of land, or
a lessee of land,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: who uses less than 0.8 hectares of the land referred to in subparagraph (i) (A) or (B), as applicable, for one or more of the following purposes:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: beekeeping;
mushroom growing;
egg production;
hog, poultry or rabbit farming;
fur farming, and

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: who received, in the immediately preceding calendar year, not less than $2 500 in gross income from the person's use of that land for any of the purposes referred to in subparagraph (ii);

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a First Nation individual who

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: uses First Nation land for a qualifying agricultural use, and
received, in the immediately preceding calendar year, not less than $2 500 in gross income from the qualifying agricultural use of the First Nation land;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person who uses land located outside British Columbia for a qualifying agricultural use and, in the immediately preceding calendar year,

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the area of the land is less than 0.8 hectares, received not less than $10 000 in gross income from the qualifying agricultural use of the land,
if the area of the land is not less than 0.8 hectares but not more than 4 hectares, received not less than $2 500 in gross income from the qualifying agricultural use of the land, or

if the area of the land is more than 4 hectares, received gross income from the qualifying agricultural use of the land that is not less than the total of $2 500 plus 5% of the assessed value of the area of land in excess of 4 hectares, for the purpose of real property taxation, in the jurisdiction in which the land is located;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: qualifying school means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a school, as defined in the School Act;
a francophone school;
a Provincial school;
an independent school, as defined in the Independent School Act;

a school operated by a participating First Nation or a Community Education Authority established by one or more participating First Nations under the First Nations Jurisdiction over Education in British Columbia Act (Canada);
a school operated by the Nisg̱a'a Nation, or a treaty first nation, under its own laws;
an institution, as defined in the College and Institute Act;
a university;
an institution that holds a designation certificate or an interim designation certificate as defined in the Private Training Act;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: reserve has the same meaning as in the Indian Act (Canada);
residential dwelling means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a house, a cottage or another detached dwelling;
a duplex;
an apartment, a condominium or a townhouse;
an apartment building, or a condominium or townhouse complex, that is used solely for the purpose of single family dwellings;
an assisted living residence, as defined in the Community Care and Assisted Living Act;
a long-term residential care facility;
a part of a multi-use building that is used for a residential use;
land that is attributable to a building, or part of a building, referred to in paragraphs (a) to (g) and that is used for a residential use,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a building, or part of a building, referred to in paragraphs (a) to (g) while the building or part is under original construction;
that part of a hotel, motel, lodge or resort, or of another building or part of a building, providing short-term lodging;
a hospital or other institutional building;
a bunk house or camp building, for use in connection with a commercial or construction project;
those parts of a building that are used for any purpose other than a residential use;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: residential energy product means any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: electricity;
natural gas;
heating oil that is coloured within the meaning of section 16.1 of the Motor Fuel Tax Act;
butane;
naphtha;
kerosene;
methanol;
heat, including transferred energy that results in cooling;
steam;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: residential use does not include use for a business, commercial or industrial purpose;
spouse means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is married to another person, or
is living with another person in a marriage-like relationship, and has been living in that relationship for a continuous period of at least 2 years;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: surrendered lands has the same meaning as in the Indian Act (Canada).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The definition of "month" in section 1 [definitions] of the Act does not apply for the purposes of this regulation.
In Schedules 2 [Tangible Personal Property for Farm Purpose] and 4 [Tangible Personal Property for Aquaculture Purpose], qualifying all-terrain vehicle means an all-terrain vehicle that

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is self-propelled,
has at least 4 wheels,
is designed primarily for use on unprepared surfaces, and
is not eligible to be licensed for use on a highway in British Columbia, except in accordance with section 24.03 [utility vehicles] of the Motor Vehicle Act Regulations, B.C. Reg. 26/58.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Interpretation of Schedule 2

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The tangible personal property described in Schedule 2 [Tangible Personal Property for Farm Purpose] does not include hoop house frames.
In Schedule 2, the titles of Tables 1 to 14

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are not part of this regulation, and
are to be considered to have been added editorially for convenience of reference only.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Heat pump
bcl:section.bcl:text: For the purposes of the definition of "heat pump" in section 1 of the Act, a heat pump means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a heat pump unit and any parts or components included as part of the heat pump unit on the initial purchase of the unit, or
a hybrid heat pump unit that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is a single factory-integrated unit, and
combines a heat pump and a furnace, boiler, water heater or similar system

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: and any parts or components included as part of the hybrid heat pump unit on the initial purchase of the unit.

bcl:part.bcl:text: Exemptions in Relation to Tangible Personal Property

bcl:division.bcl:text: Health and Medical Products and Equipment for Individuals with Disabilities

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Drugs and health products

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drugs specified in Schedule I or IA of the Drug Schedules Regulation, B.C. Reg. 9/98;
a vaccine that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: specified in Schedule II of the Drug Schedules Regulation, B.C. Reg. 9/98, or
a veterinary drug, as defined in section 1 of the Veterinary Drugs Act;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drugs and other substances for the treatment, mitigation or prevention of a disease or disorder, if the drugs and other substances are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: sold on the prescription of a practitioner, or
provided as part of a promotional distribution by a pharmaceutical company to a practitioner;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: tangible personal property that is the result of a medical imaging procedure;
drugs and other substances that alleviate pain and are in a form designed to be taken internally, whether orally or otherwise, or applied externally;
artificial limbs and orthopaedic appliances;
hearing aids;
dentures, including adhesives, liners and repair kits for dentures;
dental and optical appliances, if

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the appliances are sold on the prescription of a practitioner or a person registered as a member of the College of Opticians of British Columbia, or

the appliances are provided as part of a promotional distribution to a practitioner or a person registered as a member of the College of Opticians of British Columbia and are otherwise available to patients only by prescription;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: clip-on sunglasses, if the sunglasses are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: obtained together with eyeglasses that are exempt under paragraph (i) of this subsection, and
specifically designed to be attached to the eyeglasses;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sanitary napkins, tampons, sanitary belts, menstrual cups or other similar products, advertised or marketed substantially for feminine hygiene purposes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: vitamins and dietary supplements or adjuncts, in a form designed to be ingested orally, if the vitamins, supplements or adjuncts are obtained for human consumption;

nicotine gum, nicotine patches and similar items, advertised or marketed as products that assist an individual to stop smoking tobacco, if the gum, patches or other similar items are obtained by or on behalf of an individual for the individual's own use.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Household medical aids

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), drugs and medicines, including those in the form of salves, ointments, nasal sprays, inhalants, antiseptics, liniments, foot powders, germicides, laxatives, cough syrups and cold and flu remedies, that are

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: advertised or marketed as products for the treatment, mitigation or prevention of a disease or disorder in humans, and
commonly known as household medical aids

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.
The exemption under subsection (1) does not apply to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: sunscreen;
oral hygiene products, including toothpaste and mouthwash;
toiletries, shaving products, depilatories and fragrances;
soaps and moisturizers, unless the soap or moisturizer is medicated and is advertised or marketed as a product for the treatment, mitigation or prevention of a particular skin condition;
hair products, unless the hair product is advertised or marketed as a product for the treatment of head lice;
beauty products and cosmetics.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if obtained for use in the treatment of humans:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bunion, callus and corn pads;
first aid materials.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Exception — cannabis
bcl:section.bcl:text: The exemptions under sections 3 and 4, other than under section 3 (1) (a), do not apply to cannabis within the meaning of the Cannabis Control and Licensing Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Diabetic and ostomy supplies
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: syringes, needles, autolets, glucose monitoring units and diabetic testing materials obtained by a diabetic, or an individual on behalf of a diabetic, for the diabetic's own use;
material, equipment and supplies

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: designed for use by individuals who, as a result of surgery, are in the permanent condition of being able to dispose of their bodily wastes only through a surgically constructed bodily orifice, and
obtained by an individual with such a condition, or another individual on behalf of the individual, for that individual's own use,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: but not including skin creams, deodorants, cleaning materials or any other products that by their general nature are generally used for other purposes or by other individuals.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Human parts and reproductive products
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: human organs;
human tissue;
human semen;
human ova;
human blood;
human blood constituents.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Devices for use in transportation of individuals with disabilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if obtained for use in the transportation of individuals with disabilities:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wheelchairs and carriages, whether or not power-operated, and parts and accessories designed for them;
special controls to enable individuals with disabilities to operate electronic wheelchairs and carriages;
patient lifters;

specially designed household elevators, including wheelchair elevators, for individuals with disabilities, and materials obtained for use to build specially designed household elevators for individuals with disabilities, if the elevators become real property upon installation;
power-operated and manually operated lifts designed to facilitate entry to otherwise inaccessible buildings, structures or vehicles, including automatic tailgates or side lifts for motor vehicles;
specially designed ramps to move a wheelchair and the occupant into a motor vehicle or building;
auxiliary driving controls that facilitate the operation of motor vehicles by individuals with disabilities;
car-top lifts for lifting and storing wheelchairs on top of motor vehicles.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Parts and materials are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if the parts or materials

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are obtained solely for the purpose of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: modifying a motor vehicle, other than a multijurisdictional vehicle, to facilitate the use of the vehicle by, or the transportation of, an individual using a wheelchair, or
equipping a motor vehicle, other than a multijurisdictional vehicle, with an auxiliary driving control to facilitate the operation of the vehicle by an individual with a disability, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: are subsequently attached to, or become part of, the motor vehicle.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical supplies and equipment for individuals with disabilities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: equipment designed solely for use by an individual with a permanent disability;
tangible personal property designed to be implanted in an individual's body;
tangible personal property designed to be attached to an individual's body for the purpose of maintaining the individual's bodily functions;
hospital-style beds, if the beds are sold on the prescription of a practitioner;
injection locators;
commodes and hip belts for use with a commode;
crutches;
cannulae;
syringe injectors;
transfer boards and transfer chairs;
hernia trusses;
lift chairs designed to facilitate standing to sitting or sitting to standing, or both.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Equipment advertised or marketed for use solely by individuals with disabilities is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if the equipment is obtained by or on behalf of an individual with a disability for the individual's own use.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Children's clothing and footwear

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: adult-sized clothing or footwear means the following, in sizes designed for adults:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: garments;
hosiery, hats, ties, belts, suspenders, mittens and gloves;
uniforms, including uniforms for school, sports or recreational activities;
footwear;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: children's clothing means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: garments designed for babies, including bibs, baby blankets, shawls, receiving blankets, bunting bags, cloth diapers, diaper liners, plastic pants and rubber pants;
children's garments that are

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: designed for girls and of a size not greater than the size that is girls' size 16 according to the national standard applicable to the garments,
designed for boys and of a size not greater than the size that is boys' size 20 according to the national standard applicable to the garments, or
if no national standard applies to the garments, advertised or marketed as being of a size designed for children;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: hosiery, hats, ties, belts, suspenders, mittens and gloves in sizes designed for children;
uniforms in sizes designed for children, including uniforms for school, sports or recreational activities;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: children's footwear means footwear designed

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for babies, or
for girls or boys and that has an insole length of 24.25 cm or less;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: national standard means a standard of the National Standards of Canada, as they read on April 1, 2013, in the subject area CAN/CGSB-49, Garment Sizes, published by the Canadian General Standards Board;
youth organization means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a society as defined in the Societies Act,
a registered charity, or
a school

bcl:definition.bcl:text: that administers a team, activity or program that includes children under 15 years of age.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), children's clothing and children's footwear are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.
Subject to subsection (4), adult-sized clothing or footwear is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act if the adult-sized clothing or footwear is obtained for a child under 15 years of age.
The exemptions under subsections (2) and (3) do not apply to the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: aprons and smocks, if the apron or smock is designed to be worn over and to protect other clothing;
athletic equipment, including supports and pads;
costumes sold with masks, toys or accessories;
disposable diapers;
gloves advertised or marketed primarily for use in sports, other than skiing or snowboarding;
handkerchiefs;
ice skates, roller skates and inline skates;
scarves, other than scarves sold as part of a uniform;
shoe insoles and shoelaces;
snowshoes;
sport pinnies and scrimmage vests;
swimfins.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (3) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

For the purposes of section 145 (1.1) [evidence required to claim certain exemptions in relation to tangible personal property or software] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that adult-sized clothing or footwear is exempt under subsection (3) of this section, the collector is required to obtain all of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the full name, address and telephone number of that person;
the following information:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: if the adult-sized clothing or footwear is obtained by or on behalf of a youth organization, the name of the youth organization;
in any other case, the full name of the child for whom the adult-sized clothing or footwear is being obtained;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the purchase price of the adult-sized clothing or footwear;
a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Used clothing and footwear
bcl:section.bcl:text: An item of used clothing or used footwear is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the item was previously sold at a retail sale and previously used as clothing or footwear, and
the purchase price of the item is less than $100.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Clothing patterns and related materials

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Clothing patterns are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.

Subject to subsection (3), yarn, natural fibres, synthetic thread and fabric that are commonly used in making or repairing clothing are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part.
The exemption under subsection (2) does not apply to tangible personal property described in Schedule 5.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definition
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division, obtain does not include leasing tangible personal property as a lessee.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: School supplies obtained for use of student
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act if obtained for the use of a student who is enrolled in an educational program provided by a qualifying school or who is being educated in accordance with Division 4 [Home Education] of Part 2 of the School Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bags specifically designed to carry school books and supplies, other than the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: attaché cases;
backpacks;
bags with wheels;
briefcases;
knapsacks;
sports bags;
tote bags;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: drawing instruments, including geometry instruments;
erasers;
glue;
ink;
lined, unlined, drawing, graph and music manuscript paper;
paints and paint brushes, other than theatrical make-up and brushes and carrying cases associated with that make-up;
pencil and wax crayons;
pencils;
pens, other than fountain pens and nibs;
ring binders;
rulers;
school art portfolios;
work books.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: School supplies obtained by qualifying school, school board or similar authority

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), the following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if obtained by a qualifying school, school board or similar authority for the use of students or for use in instructing students:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: cellulose tape;
chalk;
charts, diagrams and maps;
lesson notes, précis, examinations, test papers, answer keys, work sheets and other similar materials, and material to manufacture those materials;
paper clips;
pens and markers for use on whiteboards;
rubber bands;
software obtained for use

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on a computer, and
substantially as a teaching aid for students;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: staples;
visual or audio aids and recordings, other than the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: educational toys, geometric forms, models, display stands and felt boards;
equipment obtained for use to record, play, project, view or access audio or video;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: wooden pencil boxes;
supplies and materials obtained for consumption in home economics courses, other than the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: cutlery, dishes, pots and pans;
table linen and towels;
bobbins, needles, scissors, sewing machine attachments and tape measures;
tools and equipment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: supplies and materials obtained for consumption in woodworking, metal working or other industrial arts courses, other than tools and equipment including drill bits, re-usable electrical and electronic parts, grinding wheels and saw blades;
animals, either living or dead, and parts of animals, obtained for use in scientific research or experiments;
supplies and materials, including chemicals, obtained for consumption in science courses, other than the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: alcohol burner wicks;
containers obtained for use as hazardous waste disposal units for phlebotomy sharps;
fossils, rocks, minerals and other geological specimens;
gas lighter flints;
glassware;
lubricants obtained for use to maintain and prevent spotting, staining and rusting of surgical instruments;
needles;
non-disposable gloves;
osteological preparations;
animal feed;
supplies for animals;
prepared microscope slides;
preserved specimens for display;
skeletons;
surgical instruments;
syringes;
tools and equipment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: supplies and materials obtained for consumption in arts courses, other than the following:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: instrument picks and strings;
tools and equipment;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: supplies and materials obtained for consumption in commercial or business courses, other than tools and equipment;
supplies and materials obtained for consumption in vocational training courses, other than tools and equipment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are not exempt under subsection (1):

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: chalkboards, chalkboard erasers and chalkboard cleaning materials;
whiteboards, whiteboard erasers and whiteboard cleaning materials;
software obtained for use

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: on a computer, and
by teachers to assess or evaluate students or to report on students' progress;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: plaques, trophies, awards, certificates and stickers.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Photocopier toner obtained by a qualifying school, school board or similar authority is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act in respect of the portion of the photocopier toner that can reasonably be attributed to the use of the toner in making copies

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for the use of students, or
for use in instructing students.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsections (1) and (3) of this section are prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Definitions
bcl:section.bcl:text: In this Division:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: advertising and promotional content, in relation to a magazine, periodical or newspaper, includes the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: all advertisements, promotional material and promotional articles, irrespective of who bears the cost for the publication of the advertisement, promotional material or promotional article;
all material and articles paid for or sponsored by a person who is not an owner or publisher of the magazine, periodical or newspaper;
maps, charts, pictures and diagrams that are related to, or are a part of, the advertising and promotional content;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: editorials, news and articles of local or common interest content, in relation to a newspaper, includes the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maps, charts, pictures and diagrams that are related to, or are a part of, that content;
the masthead;
the title page;
public service listings of events, activities or attractions for which no consideration of any kind is paid or exchanged and for which editorial control rests solely with the publisher;
business market quotations;
sports scores;
movie, theatre and other reviews;
weather forecasts;
comics;
crosswords and similar puzzles;
horoscopes;
television listings;
letters to the editor,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include excluded content and advertising and promotional content;
excluded content, in relation to a publication, means covers, indices, tables of contents, borders and duplicated or blank pages;
excluded publication means the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: directories, programs, price lists, timetables, rate books, reports, albums, course calendars, date calendars, sports or recreation calendars, brochures and pamphlets;
a publication that is published for the same or a similar purpose as a publication referred to in paragraph (a);

catalogues and similar publications whose primary purpose is to describe, or to promote or encourage the purchase, use or consumption of, tangible personal property, software, services or real property;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: magazine means a printed and bound publication in a magazine format that is issued at regular intervals each year by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a professional body,
a trade or industrial organization,
a commercial publishing firm,
a not-for-profit corporation, or
an employer to the employer's employees,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include an excluded publication;
newspaper means a printed and unbound publication in a newspaper format that is published at regular intervals each year, but does not include the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an excluded publication;
advertising material known as flyers, or advertising circulars, even if the flyers or advertising circulars are sold or given away as part of the publication;

bcl:definition.bcl:text: periodical means a printed and bound publication in a periodical format that is issued at regular intervals each year by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a professional body,
a trade or industrial organization,
a commercial publishing firm, or
a not-for-profit corporation,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include an excluded publication;
technical, literary, editorial and pictorial content, in relation to a magazine or periodical, includes

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: maps, charts, pictures and diagrams that are related to, or are a part of, that content,
the masthead, and
the title page,

bcl:definition.bcl:text: but does not include excluded content and advertising and promotional content.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Publications

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a printed and bound book that

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: contains no advertising, and
is published solely for educational, technical, cultural or literary purposes,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: but not a directory, price list, timetable, rate book, catalogue, report, fashion book, album or any other similar book;
an employee newsletter;
a student yearbook;
sheet music;
a magazine or periodical if at least 10% of the content is composed of technical, literary, editorial and pictorial content;
a newspaper if at least 20% of the content is composed of editorials, news and articles of local or common interest content.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: If a publication is sold or given away with another publication, a determination of whether each publication qualifies for an exemption under subsection (1) (e) or (f) must be based on the content of each publication considered separately.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Calculation of content of magazines, periodicals and newspapers

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 16 (1) (e), the technical, literary, editorial and pictorial content of a magazine or periodical must be calculated by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determining the area of all the pages of the magazine or periodical,
determining the area of the excluded content of the magazine or periodical,
subtracting the area determined under paragraph (b) of this subsection from the area determined under paragraph (a),
determining the area of the technical, literary, editorial and pictorial content of the magazine or periodical, and
calculating, as a percentage, the proportion that the area determined under paragraph (d) of this subsection is to the area that results from the calculation under paragraph (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 16 (1) (f), the editorials, news and articles of local or common interest content of a newspaper must be calculated by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: determining the area of all the pages of the newspaper,
determining the area of the excluded content of the newspaper,
subtracting the area determined under paragraph (b) of this subsection from the area determined under paragraph (a),
determining the area of the editorials, news and articles of local or common interest content of the newspaper, and
calculating, as a percentage, the proportion that the area determined under paragraph (d) of this subsection is to the area that results from the calculation under paragraph (c).

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Gifts

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: person does not include a registered charity;
tangible personal property does not include a vehicle, boat or aircraft.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section, a person is exempt from tax imposed under section 49 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for use] of the Act in respect of tangible personal property if the person received the tangible personal property as a gift from a donor.
Subject to subsection (4), the exemption under subsection (2) applies to a person in respect of tangible personal property only if the donor of the tangible personal property

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: paid tax under the Act or the Social Service Tax Act in respect of the tangible personal property and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under those Acts, a refund of that tax,

paid tax under section 165 (2), 212.1 or 218.1 or Division IV.1 of Part IX of the Excise Tax Act in respect of the tangible personal property and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under Part IX of that Act, a refund of or a credit or rebate for that tax,
paid sales tax in respect of the tangible personal property to another province and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain a refund of or a credit or rebate for that sales tax,
received, before April 1, 2013, the tangible personal property as a gift in British Columbia, or
was exempt, when that donor obtained the tangible personal property, from tax

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under the Social Service Tax Act, or
under the Act, other than under section 26 [tangible personal property shipped outside British Columbia] of this regulation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemption under subsection (2) does not apply to a person in respect of tangible personal property if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the donor of the tangible personal property paid tax in respect of the tangible personal property only under one or both of section 51 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for temporary use] of the Act and section 12 [calculation of tax if use in British Columbia temporary] of the Social Service Tax Act, and

the total amount of tax referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection is less than the amount of tax that, but for subsection (2) of this section, would be payable by the person under section 49 of the Act in respect of the tangible personal property.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Gifts between family members

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section:

bcl:definition.bcl:text: donor, in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft, means the related individual from whom the person referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (b) received the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift;
related individual includes a sibling.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person is exempt from tax imposed under sections 49 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for use] and 50 [tax on registration of vehicle brought into British Columbia] of the Act in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the person received the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift from a related individual, and

a person is exempt from tax imposed under section 100 [tax on gift of vehicle, boat or aircraft in British Columbia] of the Act in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the person receives the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift from a related individual.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (5), the exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft only if the donor of the vehicle, boat or aircraft

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: paid tax under the Act, the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under those Acts, a refund of that tax,

paid tax under section 165 (2), 212.1 or 218.1 or Division IV.1 of Part IX of the Excise Tax Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under Part IX of that Act, a refund of or a credit or rebate for that tax,
paid sales tax in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft to another province and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain a refund of or a credit or rebate for that sales tax,
received, before April 1, 2013, the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift in British Columbia, or
was exempt, when that donor obtained the vehicle, boat or aircraft, from tax

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act, or
under the Act, other than under any of the following provisions of this regulation:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: section 23 [vehicle, boat or aircraft brought into British Columbia for gift];
section 24 [vehicle purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 25 [aircraft purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 26 [tangible personal property shipped outside British Columbia].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) do not apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the donor of the vehicle, boat or aircraft

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: received the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift during the 12 months before the date on which the donor gave that vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift to the person referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (b), and
was exempt under subsection (2) (a) or (b) from tax imposed under the Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft,

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: unless the donor received the vehicle, boat or aircraft referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection as a gift from the person referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (b).
The exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) do not apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the donor of the vehicle, boat or aircraft paid tax in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft only under one or both of section 51 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for temporary use] of the Act and section 12 [calculation of tax if use in British Columbia temporary] of the Social Service Tax Act, and

the total amount of tax referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection is less than the amount of tax that, but for subsection (2) (a) or (b) of this section, would be payable by the person under section 49, 50 or 100 of the Act, as applicable, in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 30 (7) (a) [evidence required to claim exemption in relation to tax payable in respect of vehicle] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that a vehicle is exempt under subsection (2) (a) or (b) of this section, the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia is required to obtain a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Registered charities

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a registered charity is exempt from tax imposed under sections 49 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for use] and 50 [tax on registration of vehicle brought into British Columbia] of the Act in respect of tangible personal property if the registered charity received the tangible personal property as a gift from a donor, and

a registered charity is exempt from tax imposed under section 100 [tax on gift of vehicle, boat or aircraft in British Columbia] of the Act in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the registered charity receives the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift from a donor.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (3), the exemptions under subsection (1) (a) and (b) apply to a registered charity in respect of tangible personal property only if the donor of the tangible personal property

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: paid tax under the Act, the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act in respect of the tangible personal property and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under those Acts, a refund of that tax,

paid tax under section 165 (2), 212.1 or 218.1 or Division IV.1 of Part IX of the Excise Tax Act in respect of the tangible personal property and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under Part IX of that Act, a refund of or a credit or rebate for that tax,
paid sales tax in respect of the tangible personal property to another province and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain a refund of or a credit or rebate for that sales tax,
received, before April 1, 2013, the tangible personal property as a gift in British Columbia, or
was exempt, when that donor obtained the tangible personal property, from tax

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act, or
under the Act, other than under any of the following provisions of this regulation:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: section 23 [vehicle, boat or aircraft brought into British Columbia for gift];
section 24 [vehicle purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 25 [aircraft purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 26 [tangible personal property shipped outside British Columbia].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemptions under subsection (1) (a) and (b) do not apply to a person in respect of tangible personal property if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the donor of the tangible personal property paid tax in respect of the tangible personal property only under one or both of section 51 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for temporary use] of the Act and section 12 [calculation of tax if use in British Columbia temporary] of the Social Service Tax Act, and

the total amount of tax referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection is less than the amount of tax that, but for subsection (1) (a) or (b) of this section, would be payable by the person under section 49, 50 or 100 of the Act, as applicable, in respect of the tangible personal property.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 30 (7) (a) [evidence required to claim exemption in relation to tax payable in respect of vehicle] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that a vehicle is exempt under subsection (1) (a) or (b) of this section, the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia is required to obtain a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Prizes, draws and awards

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, donor, in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft, means the person from whom the person referred to in subsection (2) (a) or (b) received the vehicle, boat or aircraft.
Subject to this section,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person is exempt from tax imposed under sections 49 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for use] and 50 [tax on registration of vehicle brought into British Columbia] of the Act in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the person received the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a result of any of the circumstances described in subsection (3) of this section, and

a person is exempt from tax imposed under section 100 [tax on gift of vehicle, boat or aircraft given in British Columbia] of the Act in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the person receives the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a result of any of the circumstances described in subsection (3) of this section.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (4), the exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft only if the person received the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a result of any of the following circumstances:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a lawful lottery scheme within the meaning of section 207 of the Criminal Code;
a contest, game of chance or skill, or mixed chance and skill, or a disposition by any mode of chance, skill or mixed chance and skill;
an achievement in a field of endeavour, including athletic or sporting events;

a draw or awarding of a prize if the only consideration provided by the person who received the vehicle, boat or aircraft is in the form of an entrance or admission fee, a ticket fee or another similar charge.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) do not apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if the person received the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a result of a private arrangement, including a wager, between 2 or more persons.
Subject to subsection (6), the exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft only if the donor of the vehicle, boat or aircraft

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: paid tax under the Act, the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under those Acts, a refund of that tax,

paid tax under section 165 (2), 212.1 or 218.1 or Division IV.1 of Part IX of the Excise Tax Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under Part IX of that Act, a refund of or a credit or rebate for that tax,
paid sales tax in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft to another province and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain a refund of or a credit or rebate for that sales tax,
received, before April 1, 2013, the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift in British Columbia, or
was exempt, when that donor obtained the vehicle, boat or aircraft, from tax

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act, or
under the Act, other than under any of the following provisions of this regulation:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: section 23 [vehicle, boat or aircraft brought into British Columbia for gift];
section 24 [vehicle purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 25 [aircraft purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 26 [tangible personal property shipped outside British Columbia].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemptions under subsection (2) (a) and (b) do not apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, boat or aircraft if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the donor of the vehicle, boat or aircraft paid tax in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft only under one or both of section 51 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for temporary use] of the Act and section 12 [calculation of tax if use in British Columbia temporary] of the Social Service Tax Act, and

the total amount of tax referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection is less than the amount of tax that, but for subsection (2) (a) or (b) of this section, would be payable by the person under section 49, 50 or 100 of the Act, as applicable, in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: For the purposes of section 30 (7) (a) [evidence required to claim exemption in relation to tax payable in respect of vehicle] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that a vehicle is exempt under subsection (2) (a) or (b) of this section, the Insurance Corporation of British Columbia is required to obtain a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:hnote: [am. B.C. Reg. 216/2013, App. 1, s. 5 and App. 2, s. 2.]

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Inheritance of tangible personal property
bcl:section.bcl:text: Tangible personal property transferred as part of the distribution of a deceased individual's estate is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.

bcl:division.bcl:text: Tangible Personal Property Entering or Leaving British Columbia

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: New resident's effects — tangible personal property

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Tangible personal property is exempt from tax imposed under sections 49 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for use], 50 [tax on registration of vehicle brought into British Columbia] and 55 [property brought into British Columbia from outside Canada] of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tangible personal property is brought or sent into British Columbia, or delivery of the tangible personal property is received in British Columbia, by an individual for use solely for a non-business purpose,
the tangible personal property enters British Columbia within one year of the individual becoming a resident of British Columbia, and
the tangible personal property is owned and has been owned by the individual for a continuous period of at least 30 days before the individual becomes a resident of British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Tangible personal property is exempt from tax imposed under sections 49, 50 and 55 of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tangible personal property is brought or sent into British Columbia, or delivery of the tangible personal property is received in British Columbia, by an individual for use solely for a non-business purpose,
the individual became a resident of British Columbia on or after March 11, 2019,
the tangible personal property enters British Columbia on or before the earlier of

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: January 1, 2023, and
the date that is one year after the date that the last order made under section 58 of the Quarantine Act (Canada) in relation to COVID-19 ceases to have effect, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tangible personal property is owned and has been owned by the individual for a continuous period of at least 30 days before the individual becomes a resident of British Columbia.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Tangible personal property that qualified for an exemption under subsection (1) or (1.1) on the entry date of the tangible personal property and that is subsequently used for a business purpose is exempt from tax imposed under section 82 [tax if property used for new purpose] of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the use of the tangible personal property for a business purpose does not begin within the first 6 months after the entry date of the tangible personal property,
the tangible personal property

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: is not a vehicle, a boat or an aircraft, and
was owned by the individual referred to in subsection (1) or (1.1) for more than 3 years before the individual became a resident of British Columbia, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the individual referred to in subsection (1) or (1.1)

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: previously paid tax under the Act or the Social Service Tax Act in respect of the tangible personal property and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under those Acts, a refund of that tax,

previously paid tax under section 165 (2), 212.1 or 218.1 or Division IV.1 of Part IX of the Excise Tax Act in respect of the tangible personal property and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under Part IX of that Act, a refund of or a credit or rebate for that tax, or
previously paid sales tax in respect of the tangible personal property to another province and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain a refund of or a credit or rebate for that sales tax.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Vehicle, boat or aircraft brought into British Columbia for gift

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsections (2) and (3), a person who is a BC resident is exempt from tax imposed under section 49 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for use] of the Act in respect of a vehicle, a boat or an aircraft if the person brings or sends into British Columbia, or receives delivery of in British Columbia, the vehicle, boat or aircraft solely for the purpose of giving that vehicle, boat or aircraft to another person as a gift.
The exemption under subsection (1) applies to a person in respect of a vehicle, a boat or an aircraft only if the person

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: previously paid tax under the Act, the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under those Acts, a refund of that tax,

previously paid tax under section 165 (2), 212.1 or 218.1 or Division IV.1 of Part IX of the Excise Tax Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain, under Part IX of that Act, a refund of or a credit or rebate for that tax,
previously paid sales tax in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft to another province and has not obtained and is not entitled to obtain a refund of or a credit or rebate for that sales tax,
received, before April 1, 2013, the vehicle, boat or aircraft as a gift in British Columbia, or
was exempt, when that person obtained the vehicle, boat or aircraft, from tax

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: under the Consumption Tax Rebate and Transition Act or the Social Service Tax Act, or
under the Act, other than under any of the following provisions of this regulation:

bcl:clause.bcl:text: section 24 [vehicle purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 25 [aircraft purchased for use outside British Columbia];
section 26 [tangible personal property shipped outside of British Columbia].

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemption under subsection (1) does not apply to a person in respect of a vehicle, a boat or an aircraft if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the person previously paid tax in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft only under one or both of section 51 [tangible personal property brought into British Columbia for temporary use] of the Act and section 12 [calculation of tax if use in British Columbia temporary] of the Social Service Tax Act, and

the total amount of tax referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection is less than the amount of tax that, but for subsection (1) of this section, would be payable by the person under section 49 of the Act in respect of the vehicle, boat or aircraft.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Vehicle purchased for use outside British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, qualifying vehicle means a vehicle that is registrable under the vehicle registration legislation, but does not include a multijurisdictional vehicle or a trailer that is used with a multijurisdictional vehicle.
A qualifying vehicle is exempt from tax imposed under section 37 [tax on purchase of tangible personal property] of the Act if the qualifying vehicle

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is purchased by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a person other than an individual, or
an individual who does not reside or ordinarily reside in British Columbia,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is purchased for use primarily outside British Columbia,
is not purchased for use in British Columbia, other than for a non-business purpose, and
will not be registered under the vehicle registration legislation.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (2) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

For the purposes of section 145 (1.1) (a) [evidence required to claim certain exemptions in relation to tangible personal property or software] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that a qualifying vehicle is exempt under subsection (2) of this section, the collector is required to obtain a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Aircraft purchased for use outside British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An aircraft is exempt from tax imposed under section 37 [tax on purchase of tangible personal property] of the Act if the aircraft

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is purchased by

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a person other than an individual, or
an individual who does not reside or ordinarily reside in British Columbia,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is purchased for use primarily outside British Columbia, and
is not purchased for use in British Columbia, other than for a non-business purpose.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

For the purposes of section 145 (1.1) (a) [evidence required to claim certain exemptions in relation to tangible personal property or software] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that an aircraft is exempt under subsection (1) of this section, the collector is required to obtain a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tangible personal property shipped outside British Columbia

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: A purchaser who purchases tangible personal property at a sale in British Columbia is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tangible personal property is to be shipped by the seller for delivery outside British Columbia, and

no use is to be made of the tangible personal property by the purchaser while the tangible personal property is in British Columbia other than storage of the tangible personal property with the seller.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Fuel for use as source of energy

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: pelletized fuel, as defined in the Solid Fuel Burning Domestic Appliance Regulation;
manufactured firelogs;
barbecue briquettes.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Wood and charcoal are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if obtained for use as a source of energy.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Residential energy products
bcl:section.bcl:text: A residential energy product is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Divisions 9 and 11 of that Part, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the residential energy product is obtained solely for residential use in a residential dwelling,
the seller of the residential energy product delivers or provides the residential energy product to

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a residential dwelling,
a building that contains a residential dwelling, or
a storage tank or facility located at and connected to a residential dwelling, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: in the case of a delivery or provision of a residential energy product to a residential dwelling that is part of a multi-use building, the seller delivers or provides the residential energy product to a storage tank or facility, or through a meter, that services only the part of the building that is used only for residential use.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Electricity for residential and farm use

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Electricity is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the electricity is obtained by a qualifying farmer for use only for

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: residential use in a residential dwelling, and
a farm purpose, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the seller of the electricity provides the electricity for both purposes described in paragraph (a) through the same meter.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

For the purposes of section 145 (1.1) [evidence required to claim certain exemptions in relation to tangible personal property or software] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that electricity is exempt under subsection (1) of this section, the collector is required to obtain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the name, address, card number and expiry date as recorded on a BC Farmer Identity Card issued to that person by the BC Agriculture Council, or
a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Continuous supply of tangible personal property as part of use of real property or moorage facilities
bcl:section.bcl:text: Tangible personal property is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the tangible personal property is purchased from a seller under a contract that has as its fundamental and overriding objective the right to use real property or moorage facilities and not the purchase of the tangible personal property,
the seller delivers the tangible personal property or makes the tangible personal property available to the purchaser on a continuous basis by means of a wire, pipeline or other conduit,
the seller does not deliver or provide the tangible personal property to the purchaser through a separate meter, and
the seller of the tangible personal property obtained the tangible personal property from another person for a purpose other than for the sole purpose of resale.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Energy conservation
bcl:section.bcl:text: The following tangible personal property is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if the tangible personal property is obtained for use to conserve energy:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: thermal insulation material that is

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: a batt, a blanket, a roll, a panel, loose fill or cellular plastic material, and
designed primarily to prevent heat loss from a building,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: but not including vapour barrier or any other material incorporated into or attached to a building and serving a structural or decorative function;
polystyrene forming blocks designed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: for use initially as a form for concrete, and
to remain permanently attached to the concrete to serve as the primary insulation for the completed building to prevent heat loss from the building;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: fastening components specifically designed for use with polystyrene forming blocks described in paragraph (b);
chemicals obtained for use to make spray polyurethane foam insulation designed primarily to prevent heat loss from a building;

window insulating systems, consisting of a transparent or translucent film and including frames or integral parts of the systems, installed in an existing window and designed primarily to retain heat in a building by absorbing solar heat or reducing drafts;
weather stripping and caulking materials designed to prevent heat loss from a building;
insulation, other than tapes and sealants, designed to prevent the transfer of heat to or from hot water tanks, hot or cold water pipes or ductwork;
wind-powered generating equipment specifically designed to produce mechanical or electrical energy;

generators, controllers, wiring and devices that convert direct current into alternating current, if they are obtained together with and as part of wind-powered generating equipment described in paragraph (h);
solar photovoltaic collector panels;
controllers, wiring and devices that convert direct current into alternating current, if they are obtained together with and as part of a system that includes solar photovoltaic collector panels;
solar thermal collector panels;
wiring, pumps, tubing and heat exchangers, if they are obtained together with and as part of a system that includes solar thermal collector panels;
micro-hydro turbines and generators designed to produce up to 150 kW of mechanical or electrical energy;

controllers, wiring, tubing and devices that convert direct current into alternating current, if they are obtained together with and as part of a system that includes micro-hydro turbines or generators described in paragraph (n);
equipment specifically designed to produce mechanical or electrical energy from ocean tides, currents or waves;
the following, if obtained together with and as part of a system that includes equipment described in paragraph (p):

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: generators, wiring, controllers, monitors, pumps, tubing, floats, water fences and devices that convert direct current into alternating current;
aids to navigation as defined in section 125 of the Canada Shipping Act, 2001;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: natural gas and propane conversion kits for internal combustion engines;
kits to convert motor vehicles to operate solely on electricity;
the following, if designed to reduce wind-resistance and improve fuel efficiency:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: tractor-trailer gap fairings;
trailer side skirts;
aerodynamic bumpers;
tank skirts;
tractor roof fairings;
base flaps;
boat tails.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Heat pumps
bcl:section.bcl:text: Heat pumps are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Tangible personal property for use for hydroelectric power generation

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Tangible personal property described in Schedule 1 [Tangible Personal Property for Hydroelectric Power Generation] is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if the tangible personal property is

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: manufactured machinery, equipment or apparatus,
obtained for use

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: as penstock intake or diversion equipment, at the point of diversion from the water source, or
as penstock pipe, to provide water from the point of diversion from the water source to a hydroelectric power plant, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: part of a penstock system for a hydroelectric power plant that is validly licensed under the Water Sustainability Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

For the purposes of section 145 (1.1) [evidence required to claim certain exemptions in relation to tangible personal property or software] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that tangible personal property is exempt under subsection (1) of this section, the collector is required to obtain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that person's registration number, or
if that person does not have a registration number, a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Work-related safety equipment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following work-related safety equipment designed to be worn by a worker is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: safety glasses, safety goggles, face shields and welding helmets;
respirators that offer protection from dust, toxic gases and vapours, including protection canisters;
gas masks, including protection canisters;
hearing protectors, including ear down, ear plugs and ear muffs;
safety caps, hard hats and helmets, but not including optional weather liners, skull caps, hairnets or sweatbands;

gloves with built-in safety features such as reinforced thumbs, palms or cuffs, designed to protect the wearer from physical harm, including traffic safety gloves to enhance visibility, but not including dress gloves, general purpose gloves and gloves designed primarily to protect the wearer from natural elements;
footwear with built-in safety features such as safety toes, loggers' caulks or acid resistance, but not including footwear designed solely for protection against the weather;
metatarsal protectors, puncture-resistant insoles, toe clips, shin guards, foot guards, skid-masters and ice cleats;
personal intercom systems designed to allow safe, hands-free communication while working in confined or hazardous environments.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: An air hose designed to connect a respirator described in subsection (1) (b) to an air source, if the air hose is obtained together with the respirator, is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Equipment and apparel for specific purpose

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subject to subsection (2), work-related safety equipment and apparel designed to be worn by or attached to a worker is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, if the work-related safety equipment or apparel is obtained by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an employer for use by the employer's employees in the course of their employment,
a person who is self-employed for the person's own use in the course of self-employment, or
an educational institution for the use of students who are enrolled in educational programs provided by that institution.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The exemption under subsection (1) applies to work-related safety equipment or apparel obtained by

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: an employer referred to in subsection (1) (a), if the work-related safety equipment or apparel is obtained for the purpose of complying with

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: the Occupational Health and Safety Regulation, B.C. Reg. 296/97, or
the Health, Safety and Reclamation Code for Mines in British Columbia established under the Mines Act, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: a person referred to in subsection (1) (b) or an educational institution referred to in subsection (1) (c), if the person or institution would have been required to obtain the work-related safety equipment or apparel for the purpose referred to in paragraph (a) of this subsection had the person or institution been an employer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Subsection (1) of this section is prescribed for the purposes of section 145 (1) (a) [provisions providing exemptions in relation to tangible personal property] of the Act.

For the purposes of section 145 (1.1) [evidence required to claim certain exemptions in relation to tangible personal property or software] of the Act, in relation to a person who alleges that tangible personal property is exempt under subsection (1) of this section, the collector is required to obtain

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: that person's registration number, or
if that person does not have a registration number, a declaration in a form acceptable to the director.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Marine safety equipment

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: floater coats;
inflatable life rafts that meet the requirements of the Life Saving Equipment Regulations under the Canada Shipping Act, 2001 for inflatable life rafts, and repair kits for those rafts;
life jackets;
life-saving buoys and flags;
life-saving cushions;
life-saving throw rings;
marine survival suits.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Distress flares are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if obtained for use on a boat to draw attention to the boat when the boat is in distress.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Safety equipment and apparel

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: bicycle lights and reflectors;
children's restraint car seats;
children's booster car seats;
first aid kits;
safety helmets designed for use in sport, recreation or transportation;
safety vests and safety bibs, the sole purpose of which is to enhance the visibility of the wearer;
emergency locator transmitters;
portable fire extinguishers and refills for portable fire extinguishers;
self-contained smoke or fire alarm devices designed for use in residential dwellings and sold for a purchase price per unit of less than $250;
gas detection monitors that monitor for gas on a continuous basis;
emergency gas shut-off devices

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: designed for manually shutting off the gas supply of a building, or
attached to a gas line and designed to automatically shut off the gas supply to a building in response to significant movement;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following avalanche safety and rescue equipment:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: avalanche airbag backpack systems specifically designed to carry airbags that, when triggered, inflate instantly to help keep the wearer above the snow surface during an avalanche;
avalanche beacons and probes to help locate avalanche victims;

equipment specifically designed to reduce the likelihood of asphyxiation from the formation of an ice mask on a person who is buried under snow by providing an artificial air pocket through which air is taken from the surrounding snowpack;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: personal alert safety systems designed

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: to be worn by persons working in hazardous or potentially hazardous conditions, and
to alert

bcl:clause.bcl:text: the wearer to unsafe conditions, or
rescuers to the location of the wearer;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: automated external defibrillators, kits containing an automated external defibrillator and pads designed for use with automated external defibrillators.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The following are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the following emergency equipment if obtained for use on highways:

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: distress flares;
fluorescent tape;
reflective strips for barriers;
reflectors;
triangle emblems;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: oxygen, oxygen containers or oxygen dispensing apparatus, obtained for medical or emergency use;
air compressors obtained for use to fill oxygen containers or oxygen dispensing apparatus, if the container or apparatus is for emergency use by a firefighter;
transmitters designed for use solely to communicate the existence of a medically related emergency, if the transmitter is obtained by an individual for use

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: at the individual's residence, or
by another individual at the other individual's residence.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Mining supplies

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this section, explosive supplies means blasting agents, blasting supplies and blasting accessories, including blasting caps, boosters, plastic cap holders, electric starters, squibs, shunt connectors, safety fuse assemblies, igniter cord connectors, hot wire lighters, detonator cord connectors and closing tubes.
Explosive supplies are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if obtained for use in

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: mineral exploration, extraction or processing, or
the development of a mine other than construction of an access road to a mine.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Balls, rods and similar detached media obtained for use in the grinding of ore in the process of extracting minerals from ore are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Boomsticks and used boom gear

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: Boomsticks are exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act.
The following boom gear is exempt from tax imposed under Part 3 of the Act, other than Division 9 of that Part, if the boom gear was previously sold at a retail sale and previously used as boom gear:
